stem: A 75-year-old client is 2 hours post-TURP with continuous bladder irrigation (CBI). Based on the documentation in the Metabolic & TURP Irrigation Log, which finding is the most likely indicator of TURP Syndrome?

tabs.title: Metabolic Trends
tabs.content:
TestBaseline (Pre-Op)2 Hours Post-Op
Serum Sodium (Na+)140 mEq/L122 mEq/L
Hemoglobin14.2 g/dL11.8 g/dL
Serum Osmolality290 mOsm/kg255 mOsm/kg

tabs.title: CBI Irrigation Log
tabs.content:
Irrigant Type: Glycine 1.5% (Non-electrolyte solution).
Total Irrigant In: 6,000 mL.
Total Drainage Out: 4,200 mL.
Condition: Massive absorption of irrigant suspected.

tabs.title: Nurses Notes
tabs.content: Current: Client is confused and reports 'visual disturbances' (everything looks blurred). Blood pressure is 172/96 (rising); HR 58 (bradycardic). Client is nauseated and vomiting.

options.text: The rapid drop in serum sodium to 122 mEq/L
The light pink color of the urine output
The decrease in hemoglobin from 14.2 to 11.8
The total volume of irrigant used (6,000 mL)

rationale.correct: The most definitive indicator of **TURP Syndrome (a1)** is the profound dilutional hyponatremia (Na+ 122). This occurs when the body absorbs too much of the non-electrolyte irrigation fluid (like Glycine) through the opened prostatic venous sinuses during surgery. This leads to volume overload (High BP, Bradycardia) and cerebral edema (Confusion, Nausea, Visual changes). Without correction (diuretics/sodium replacement), this can lead to seizures and death.
clinicalPearls: Classic signs: HTN, Bradycardia (Cushing-like), Confusion, and Visual Disturbance.
Treatment involves stopping the irrigation, limiting fluids, and giving hypertonic saline or diuretics.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing the Hemoglobin drop (a3) because surgery usually involves bleeding.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While the Hgb did drop, it is a *dilutional* drop (the blood is watered down by the 2 liters of absorbed irrigant), not necessarily a sign of hemorrhage. The Na+ of 122 is the specific metabolic hallmark of the syndrome.

mnemonic.title: T-U-R-P S-Y-N
mnemonic.expansion: T-Too much fluid. U-Under 135 Sodium. R-Rising BP. P-Passing out (Confusion).
